In a few words: Designing a Platform is easy, but Validating it is another story. For this an other reasons we're now starting new research together with my co-conspirators @l_ruggeri and @jacoporomei at @Boundaryless_ Check it out! https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

Liquidity ‚Äì essentially a function of the ratio between producers and consumers connected to the network ‚Äì is indeed essential for providing consumers with the right ‚Äúdepth of choice‚Äù, and  producers with a good utilization rate https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

Furthermore, another grand challenge of platform strategy development is to understand the impact that liquidity has on the perception of the value proposition and identify when critical mass will be hit, triggering then the network-effects-based growth. https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

This is a key driver of platform value vs industrial solutions: if no value is perceived in niches (finding the *right* solution for my needs through connecting with a specific provider) this is a hint that a traditional solution, might be better
https://t.co/TlLV386CFw
Another essential element that platforms need to validate is normally the perception of value related to accessing niche, highly personalized solutions.  https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

Validating your assumptions on the current ecosystem experience is essential to understand how to design the two major elements of value that the platform strategy brings: reduction of transaction costs through and evolutionary learning services
https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

In a few words, it‚Äôs the process of validating the designer‚Äôs assumptions on the ecosystem (the equivalent of validating assumptions on the ‚Äúproblem‚Äù side vs the ‚Äúsolution‚Äù side of a typical simple product VP) that is crucial. https://t.co/TlLV3864PY
Achieving this goal may be very a complex task: scanning the ecosystem, and identifying key entities and existing interactions is paramount.  https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

Moreover, any loyal adopter of our open-source exploration, design, and product growth frameworks knows that a platform is an amplifier of potential in the ecosystem, and therefore the platform strategy must be designed with attention to emergence. https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

...when you extend your product with an extension platform you‚Äôve to validate not only the core customer need but also the attraction that you can exert on vendors and third parties providing ‚Äúplug-ins‚Äù and ‚Äúapps‚Äù and other extensions in general https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

Furthermore a platform designer is often asked to validate assumptions over two sides (and more sometimes): typically indeed, as you launch a marketplace, you deal with the supply and demand side, and...
https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

‚Ä¢ risk of creating a non-viable business, despite its feasibility and its desirability, due to the fact that ‚Äì for example ‚Äì unit economics don‚Äôt work at scale with the pricing/business model used to validate the initial value proposition
https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

‚Ä¢ risk of not being able to run the product/business, even with a properly validated value proposition for a lack of technical feasibility at scale
https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

‚Ä¢ risk of creating products that lack desirability at scale (a market), due to the absence of a community of users with a common need (something which is extremely important in platforms)
https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

‚Ä¢ risk of having an excessively narrow understanding of the market opportunity and wrestling with a narrow vision of the customer
https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

A lame approach to validation introduces a series of key risks:
‚Ä¢ risk of making design choices based on assumptions, and cognitive biases, that are not representative of the real situation or opportunities.
https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

But when it comes to rigorously validating your assumptions, in terms of ecosystem structure, value perception, product features and so on, the teams I've been working with in the past have often failed to deliver.
https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

Designing a platform strategy is becoming increasingly simple: there are a lot of tools such as the #PlatformDesignToolkit that one can use to explore ecosystems and synthesize value propositions and experiences.
https://t.co/TlLV386CFw

Furthermore: "verticalization of embedded finance. As SaaS goes more vertical, so will embedded finance. The reason for this is that these hyper-focused platforms ‚Äî like Toast for restaurants ‚Äî have the data to personalize services and manage risks much more accurately"

3. "embedded finance is moving into the realm of relationship banking. ...can be orchestrated around more complex requirements [related to] large areas of under-provision [... ] where needs are better understood, incentives can be improved, and costs lowered."
2. "embedded finance is moving from single products to bundles, driving much higher value-add."
1. "scope of embedded finance is broadening (complex and heavily regulated services, such as derivatives, broader customer demographics, DeFi and Web 3.0)"

In the coming weeks, I'm going to dive deeper into these questions, with the aim of helping you understand how to approach modularity and composability in building your product, evolving your product portfolio or even defining the structure of your teams. Get in touch.

...redistributing the participating nodes the super-linear value that is created by deliberately choosing to cooperate on a supermodular standard can be a good driver of legitimacy for the system and - at the end of the day - can make a ‚Äúmodular‚Äù value proposition more appealing.
When (eco)systems are ‚Äúsupermodular‚Äù i.e generate a super-linear value for users as more components connect, or more users participate: essentially with network effects...

Composability can make the bundling of an experience based on multiple products (or product elements) easier and reduce the need to build complex adapters/wrappers but the question is always: how does one build the required legitimacy for third parties to ‚Äúagree‚Äù on a standard?

In this landscape, composability is another keyword: think web3 protocols, standard implementations, or the emergence of the ‚Äúextension platform‚Äù pattern, that large platforms use to make 3rd party ISVs develop apps that can work inside - or on top - of the platform itself.

...which is one of the pillars of our #3EO Framework https://t.co/nwcWcRNszY, can offer a way to, on one hand, ensure a good level of modularity while on the other avoid a further disconnection of teams from the market and the user.

Similarly in our Adopting a Product-Centric operating model at Scale https://t.co/7crOunVSaa we‚Äôve identified how keeping products relatively simple - ideally avoiding feature proliferation and enforcing P&L at the boundary of every product,

...or Agile 2 https://t.co/W2CHqUN1M1 of which the values seem to keep together a lot of opposites: adaptability/planning, individual empowerment/good leadership, business/tech‚Ä¶ recognizing that if we dive into autonomy w/out accountability we can get into very bad waters.

The separation between the ones responsible to identify and generate customer value and the rest of the organization has been an issue so far in many organizational development approaches and has generally triggered some kind of rebounds triggering movements such as BizDevOps...

... on the other - the need to continue pushing to unbundle the organization‚Äôs capability to create modules that can be easily rearranged, even if this means to further and increasingly disconnected from the direct perception of the customer value.

At the same time, we have to recognize that there are essentially two conflicting forces: on one side the need for teams to be ‚Äúcloser to the customer‚Äù and decide how to bundle existing components to create customer value...

this mainly as a consequence of the ever-easier access to a wide number of leverageable modules, technologies, and knowledge assets and - in general - due to a more pervasive set of enablers that are making (small) teams every day more capable of building great things.

At the same time, I often preached that the responsibility to design a consistent product (to be able to identify how value is perceived by a customer and to be accountable to this customer in the generation of such a value) should be much more pervasive in the organization...
that self-organization is a powerful way to enable organizations to reorganize quickly in a more adaptive way to respond to the challenges and opportunities arising from the market.

Modularity and self-organization have often been the subject of reflections for me and the general framing has been that modularity is a rising trend in current markets (I wrote about this here https://t.co/o79QItNMeP ) and ...
These past weeks I've been reading and thinking a lot about organizational modularity, team self-organization, and the role of management and (different types of) leadership

We recently wrote a piece on the idea of Outcooperating the Competition (@gregory_landua's TM) > https://t.co/knsBgk1G1X but questions remain largely unanswered around feasibility, legitimacy, and market dynamics.
How does a new language, taxonomy, protocol, standard get to become a foundation in the market? How do they develop legitimacy? Especially in non #blueocean markets?

Can the costs of agreeing into something be answered through the creation of new technologies (#smartcontracts), institutions (#DAOs?), or new business patterns (more keen to creating and sustaining ‚Äúmodules‚Äù and interfaces?).

The key question is: is there a chance we can develop a more cooperative internet (and market) or there are intrinsic aspects and properties of the market (capitalism?) that will always make the Darwinian competition more apt in bringing things forward?
#Web3 is bringing new ideas to the table when if comes to standardized ontologies, protocols and standards (see for example @js_horne Hyperstructures https://t.co/ZSQL1qBgzx)

At @Boundaryless_ we‚Äôre interested in understanding how these elements play out internally to organizations - and we believe this is really important as organizations unbundle into more independent teams that own their own P&L - but also *between* organizations.

If we couple this with the emergence of no-code/low-code tools we can only imagine the impacts and role that language, standardization, and shared context has and will play in the future of organizing.

The convergence between the language layer - that traditionally we would frame as part of the ‚Äúbiz‚Äù element of the organization - and the technological layer - dev, ops - has also been recently identified with the term #BizDevOps.
DDD is probably the discipline that most of all has brought up the role of shared language and shared context in the development of products and services AND organizations.
The main questions we would like to explore with @ziobrando are those related to the role of #DomainDrivenDesign in relationship with the "ontological" convergence question.

In the coming weeks we're going to have @ziobrando on the Boundaryless Conversations Podcast. Besides being the inventor of Brandolini's law (AKA the bullshit asymmetry principle) Alberto is a legend of #DDD having invented the #Eventstorming technique.

Hoping that "this is the right thing to do and we're going to fix everything" is exactly part of the approach, ethos and epistemic we need to overcome: such emergent reorganization will certainly encounter local failures and, possibly and increasingly likely, larger regional ones

A transition towards contextual/local reinvention of production chains is not going to be ‚Äúclean-cut‚Äù and universal, not a transition FROM the existing mode of production TO a new one but rather a messy, synergistic process that humanity will express, most likely under pressure.
In this exploration we need to hold off our need to often (always) frame our ideas for a new societal development as a u-turn.

Policymakers won‚Äôt certainly be kept out of the process. Instead, they will have a key role to play, but the key point remains one: self-organization will be a major driver of the real paradigm shift in production beyond business-as-usual.
Clearly, enabling policies and subsidiarity between the local, embedded players, and national and supranational players will play a role in this transitional development.

This will be done in a way that partially detaches production and consumption from the market, connecting all the constituents in a relational space where they can ‚Äúthink as an ecosystem‚Äù and do not fall back only on competition, and consumption.

Ultimately, we believe, reinventing the economic system and creating regenerative patterns is about helping stakeholders self-organizing around production chains, outside, or at the edge of the dynamics of global markets.

The more @Boundaryless we develop an understanding of what it means to embrace regenerative thinking, the more we converge on the idea of a transition towards contextualized, self-organization of stakeholders around production chains embedded in place, and webs of relationships.

If you're curious you should read the piece below. Reach out if you need help adopting such a model or you're interested in funding research on team structuring templates in scalable product-centric orgs that will be released in open source as always: https://t.co/7crOunDIW2

Furthermore, @Boundaryless_ we believe that the org need to factor in the contribution that external devs can have on products through "extension platforms": the org needs to continuously capture product innovations and facilitate the process of making new components out of them.

Finally, scaling inside each product division can be addressed through another set of patterns (tribes/squads, team topologies, micro-services and bounded contexts...) always trying to control product complexity as @onecaseman hints here https://t.co/oVfdr12OVX

The second one - adopting strategic team structures inside product divisions - is key to obtaining product outcomes: ‚Äúyou ship your org chart‚Äù they say. A new practice of structures is emerging to mimic and sustain new types of products (marketplaces, developer ecosystems...).

We believe that the first problem - defining/evolving the portfolio & product divisions - should be addressed through a solid identification of the portfolio, the definition of a product taxonomy and an investment strategy (we spoke about it here: https://t.co/6l9WlJU8he

The key insight: when adopting a Product-Centric operating model in an organization you've three levels of problem:

1. defining/evolving the portfolio & product divisions
2. adopting strategic team structures inside product divisions
3. scaling inside each product division

I'm trying to articulate how key elements of strategy (portfolio & product taxonomy views), and customer and market accountability (P&L management) can nicely interoperate with the emerging practices affirming in the space of Product Led Growth, Platforms and Ecosystems.

In this attempt, I do not expect to provide better answers than other key emerging approaches and frameworks such as the amazing @TeamTopologies, the #Spotify model (or non-model), #ScaledAgile, or other #devops practices inspired by #DomainDrivenDesign. Instead...

For this and other reasons is important to develop technologies that cover the: ‚ÄúPrimitives of Contract-based and Unit-based organizing‚Äù so that we can deliver better organizational agility and better engagement of the workforce.

If we keep the product scope focused enough, and actively seek ‚Äúplatform teams‚Äù that can be ‚Äúuntangled‚Äù from the rest - and transformed into further products - there‚Äôs a possibility that outcomes produced by the product can cascade incentives to the composing teams quite easily.
Despite not being able to play directly with P&L as a forcing function inside a product division, the composing teams can still be motivated entrepreneurially.

Research we‚Äôre doing points in the direction of distributing autonomous P&L at the border of a product division, while inside, teams structure in a way that mirrors either the product/value proposition (you ship your org chart) or other strategic initiatives.

It‚Äôs clear to me that new technologies need to be built to make it easier for teams to become more self-sovereign, collaborate across different boundaries, and leverage collaborations with other teams through dynamic agreements for the creation of new products, and strategies.
For example, in this landscape you'll see @GlassFrogApp @holaspirit @murmur @Loomio @0xMetropolis @safe @joincolony @aragonproject @coordinape @inverternetwork https://t.co/BnnCH0Jtm5

Therefore, I‚Äôm also mapping how a new set of tools is emerging that increasingly covers these ‚Äúprimitives‚Äù: managing budgets and wallets, taking decisions, setting aims/OKRs, defining agreements on objectives, creating new products/teams, and disbursing outcomes.

This is a massive culture/market shift, but also a key question around tooling: tools need to deliver an easy onboarding for organizations that want to embrace such an op. model without being caught in broken financial flows, lacking data alignment, and duplication of information

As @CharlesTBetz said a few days ago - it‚Äôs important we understand how such an operating model (see the 3EO Toolkit) and how to technologically power it because the ‚Äúcurrent hypothesis is that‚Äù such a structure ‚Äúis the end state of fully matured product-centric operating model‚Äù.

In the last few weeks, I‚Äôve been focusing on understanding better what are the key primitives that allow the most advanced organizations to work as a set of autonomous and rather self-managed units to achieve coherence.

Excellent CX will be more easily producible by leveraging on agreements between largely independent nodes and composable product/modules as I explained in my recent piece ‚ÄúTowards Modular and Composable Markets https://t.co/PSsSLFKTmA‚Äù.

Increasingly, the emergence of standardized, cross-org interfaces, that help formalize agreements, define SLAs, and distribute skin in the game to the parties involved will pose a challenge to vertically integrated organizations, making it more difficult to bear the inefficiency.

Even in such a setting, tech to manage nodes/agreements, and define how budgets integrate with incentives and OKRs/KPIs to ensure all the players work for the aspired outcomes and are motivated to be entrepreneurial, even if not directly in touch with customers are key.

These losses of efficiency are ok because the product that the division brings to the market can be more heavily differentiated and therefore gain a premium from customers that compensate for the internal inefficiency or lack of modularization.

The broader the context that has to bear a positive P&L, the more specialization can emerge internally (generally between product teams vs ‚Äúplatform‚Äù teams) because the division can manage to have an internal loss of efficiency in favor of responsiveness for shorter TTM

These high value-add services that are to be consumed widely by ‚Äúcustomer facing‚Äù teams in the division (that are responsible to ‚Äúrebundle‚Äù capabilities into products) will heavily depend on the industry context / business model.

In contexts that embrace P&L separation at bigger scales (division), intermediate specialized types of teams (those that are often called platform teams) emerge to provide key, high value-add, elements horizontally throughout the division for their internal customers to consume.

In this case, a lagging, stuck, non-responsive service unit inside the organization (being it a platform team or a shared service provider) would generate cascading inefficiencies on the units that rely on its services.

Shared services that exist bounded inside such a non-optimized space have to be optimized for ‚Äúresponsiveness‚Äù toward internal customers because they (customers) do not have the possibility to source capabilities externally.

This choice allows organizations to define clearer outcomes, pursue stricter ‚Äúpurposes‚Äù, and allow more control of the end customer experience. Such ‚Äúupsides‚Äù can be reached at the expense of efficiency, and adaptability.

Some companies may want to ensure more control over the outcomes, giving less freedom to teams, and wanting to integrate more elements ‚Äúvertically‚Äù by, for example moving, the enforcement of positive P&L to the division (or higher) level.

Enforcing P&L at the small unit level requires the organization to behave more like a venture builder and set loose strategic direction. This makes the case for technologies to allow the creation and execution of agreements between organizational nodes.

Enforcing positive P&L at the small unit makes a strong case for highly adaptable, teams that develop general capabilities internally, such as product/service design, engineering, etc‚Ä¶ they will rely on sourcing specialized capabilities at market rates (inside/outside the org).

Adopting self-managed P&L inside organizations certainly bodes for less specialized, and more generalist teams: besides very basic services that we could consider ‚Äúcommodities‚Äù we could expect that P&L-owning units must develop a certain level of plasticity.

In our work at @boundaryless_ we rely heavily on the vision of organizations as based on self-managed, independent teams and we have a strong bias for the idea that units should manage their resources, wallets, and - at the end of the day - their profit and loss statements.

In short, the road to be less ill with wants is long, tortuous, and - in some days - leaves me with some nostalgia too. But with this I believe that we must measure ourselves, at all levels, the personal, the family, the institutional. It's a long way. https://t.co/BZeuRQuRFY

...but the need to take care of @Boundaryless_ - which in recent months has also undergone a transition towards a management model less centered on me - has absorbed me, and new business ventures I'm working on in various fields, are taking me more time.

I would have liked to deal more with the initiatives that create territorial value, for example the libertarian, parent run "school" that my children attend, the food distribution / CSA coop I use for the purchase of primary goods, or other relationship focused projects...

I no longer spend my nights at the airport, or my days writing on taxis, trains, and planes. This process of re-integration with the limit, and in the process with the territory and with tangible relationships, I must say, has only partially succeeded.

I miss sometimes participating in person in some international event, but at the same time I find myself being much more productive and being able to manage my family life, my diet, my exercise much better.

My working life took place first at home, then for about 6 months in a 9 square meter office that I took in Frascati - my hermitage. I miss the old life a little, I miss Barcelona and all my friends who live there, I miss Istanbul, Fuerteventura, Greece ...

I have adopted this new lifestyle partly to reduce my carbon footprint, partly as a meditative practice, aware that it is not enough to fix a completely broken social model, but I have decided to impose limits on myself, and see how my life rearranged itself around them.

This transition for me had already started before the pandemic, in about 2018/19, I gradually began to prefer the train even for demanding trips from Rome (for example Zurich, Vienna ...) and the ship, the train or the car for the holidays.

In this period I have never expatriated - not even for the holidays that I had started to do again in Italy for a while - I have substantially abolished participation in live events both in Italy and abroad, I have abandoned the facilitation in first person.
In January 2023, it will be three years since I no longer travel by plane.

2. clear contract templates that allow teams to work together, and to agree on reciprocal promises of value as agreements that enable them to venture out and build new products and services.

Such interfaces are:
1. clear investment policies where teams can negotiate with the organization not only their duties and responsibilities but also their accountability to entrepreneurial objectives, and autonomy in building new components of the portfolio;
Indeed, as a complement to a clearer work of mapping ecosystems and products into open and discussable portfolios we advise organizations to embrace clear organizational interfaces.

Embracing an ùíâùíÜùíïùíÜùíìùíêùíèùíêùíéùíäùíÑ model of organizing is essential: many of the categories we used to understand reality in the 20th century are losing their capability to produce the insights that organizational leaders have relied upon to dictate management choices so far.

In this setting, the product and service portfolio that the organization wants to build is always mapped and synced with the abstraction we are able to build - internally - of the external market (and society more in general).

Part of the shift needed to overcome the formality of the organization of the 20th century goes through the embracement of an outside-in perspective to organizing, where ecosystems dictate the organization's direction.

In the context we're currently living, it's difficult to stay attached to antiquated ideas around organizing: it's clear that many of the boundaries we've encased our organizations within are increasingly felt as unbearable constraints, frames we've to break.

"Ecosystem-Driven Organizations: Shared Market Maps, Forcing Functions and Investing into Small Units" https://t.co/ig5f69D14v

and reach out if you want to work together in making your organization capable of becoming Ecosystem-driven

In a few words, rethinking your organization for success in a complexity goes through breaking down the organization into small teams, give them transparent access to market and portfolio analysis and empower them through standard contracts and easily available incubation capital

a certain amount of centralization in strategy is needed - also in Ecosystem Driven organizations - for two reasons:
- first, strategy identification happens at the organizational level
- second, a portfolio-based point of view that needs a preferred point of view

The problem is then to reubndle the unbundled organization around the emerging opportunities: at @Boundaryless_ we believe that the principles to be embraced are those of nudging, and of the creation of so-called ‚Äúenabling constraints"

I also explained how to extract a platform strategy model from a Value Chain analysis more practically in "Apply Value Chain Analysis with Wardley Maps to identify a Platform Opportunity" here https://t.co/xYkRl22qY5‚Äù.

First, you've to map your reference ecosystems, by breaking them down into arenas, of which you can build value chain abstractions:_check ‚ÄúFraming a Portfolio of Platform-Ecosystem strategies inside an Organization https://t.co/Zd89lAIL49‚Äù

In this setting, the strategy and the shape of the organization are dictated by what happens outside of it: markets are extremely more dynamic and complex today as well as the societal context that shifts more strongly and in faster cycles. You need more unbundling to fit.

Building an ecosystem-driven organization goes through two things:
1. becoming radically outside-in in how you look at your product portfolio
2. create enablers for teams to swarm on opportunities to build, making them entrepreneurial and accountable.

How do you build an Ecosystem-Driven Organizations?

I'm looking for resources on how to split, structure, and evolve teams in organizations that deliver one or more digital products (including SaaS, Marketplaces, developer/app platforms, and other types), and companies that look into being product-led, growth-focused.

This piece builds on the shoulders of many pioneers. I already mentioned @cdixon, and @boironattorney but of course, I've to mention: @jessewldn @ntnsndr and I also want to thank @jeffemmett @sanguit @gabelunao @adamjacksonsf @robmsolomon for inspiration

(10/10)

Lastly, I also explain how #web3 can offer new ways to implement @swardley #ILC innovation cycle, in a way that apps can be rewarded for being "future sensing engines" and not overly commoditized by the platform owner.

(9/10)

what's the role of tokens? They deliver powerful capabilities such as:
1) incentives for bootstrapping usage (to both users and apps)
2) utility: both protocol and apps can accept tokens to deliver some of their services
3) governance: tokens can be used in voting 
+more

(8/10)

building the full stack also implies raising capital for both layers: the protocol and the product. This can be done in several ways, the most common currently being a combination of SAFE/SAFT - while more advanced approaches (such as Automated Market Makers) are possible

(7/10) https://t.co/CmYUgvJOXF

full stack #web3 projects need to be competitive with centralized platforms: fees should be distributed across the layers (L1/L2 blockchain, protocol, application). We have to build more a equitable and less extractive alternative and all contributions have to be rewarded

(6/10) https://t.co/cAblMFYuDs

then I help founders ponder choosing an existing protocol vs building a new one, also explaining how the convergence over protocols could happen at the different layers of the value chain: 
- low in the value chain: more convergence
- up in the value chain: more diversity

(5/10) https://t.co/V2EF7E3BSP

Later in the piece, I look into the interplay between the #protocol and the #products (applications) - first I discern between different protocol types:
Permissioned vs Permissionless
Token-based vs Token-less
Fee-based vs Fee-less.

All very important distinctions 

(4/10) https://t.co/FBqWoOOzog

Then I look into why building in #web3 also entails that one understands @boironattorney idea of "sufficient decentralization" - to avoid that any token released is deemed as an investment contract: this could strongly limit the token distribution and your maneuver space

(3/10)

First, I look into "why" building in #web3. Besides @cdixon's original consideration on incentives alignment, I identify 4 value drivers: 
1. Enabling users control their data
2. Improve trustability towards applications
3. Leveraging Tokenomics
4. Distribute Governance

(2/10) https://t.co/YiFBuqEFtk

I just released "Building Products and Protocols in Web3: a Playbook"

I wrote this after working on the design and architecture of a few #web3 projects where I mixed my 10-year-long experience in Platform Design with web3 enablers and drivers.

https://t.co/QTCDsU6EjV 

(1/10)

It's open-source economy, on steroids.
This transition will oblige organizations to reconsider where do their boundaries stand, and will push us to rethink the meaning of things such as "organization", "purpose" and employment.

These mechanisms essentially bring such strong market-driven, Darwinian innovation dynamics that make our idea of "using P&L internally" as a forcing function for how we structure teams inside our organization, pale in comparison.

This comes at the cost of accepting a certain ontology trade-off. When incentive mechanisms also exist for participants to actually build the underlying infrastructure, the opportunities create tensions that the video of building "inside" organizations can't contain.

We are learning how to create transparent protocols as ontologically convergent and composable layers. If we accept (and participate in) these composable ontologies and build on top of them, our orgs can break free of the monopolies that characterized the last two decades.

In any case, the push for ontological convergence is strong, dictated by the requirement of efficiency that a society facing inflation, and peak resources, will require.
... creating their defensibilities through nfx/aggregation at the marketplace level (when possible), or through other defensibility strategies.

Therefore we can imagine that if an ontological model and a common data layers can be trusted, economic players will strive to build value at higher layers of the value chain, thus building platforms on top of the protocol...

"When attractive profits disappear at one stage in the value chain because a product becomes modular and commoditized, the opportunity to earn attractive profits with proprietary products will usually emerge at an adjacent stage."
Clayton Christensen

Adopting a common, intentionally shared, and cooperatively governed (by a DAO) ontology which is then not just a *de-facto* incumbent ontology makes sense from a point of view of conservation of attractive profits

Once the threat of a centralized player first providing and then discontinuing API-based access to a data layer representing a certain domain and state is removed, the case to build on shared data spaces makes a lot more sense.
First of all, this is now more achievable due to the affordance of the blockchain, which makes it possible to create permissionless and untamperable data layers.

Web3 offers new possibilities: I described the interplay between protocols and platforms in a recent post (https://t.co/k3dmgFQKws). I'm keen to think that the future of platforms will entail a higher tendency toward common low-layer protocols, bringing ontologies with them.
Open specifications, protocols, and modules constituting an open operating system will have increasing penetration in the market in the coming future.

@orgdimension Appreciate your empathizing

I criticized a lot, for years, those who thought that imagining was as important as implementing, developing and undertaking. Today I realize that, perhaps, within our routines, imagining ourselves different has become so tiring that it seems almost impossible.

An era where it is so difficult that we come to question the possibility of getting out of the sucking up of the productive, capitalist and efficiency-oriented routine, which is ironically struggling in a crisis of credibility.

Here, I find that this situation reflects the era we live in: an age in which it would be so important to re-discuss  priorities and salience, and at the same time an age of distractions, intricacies that repeat themselves indefinitely, detachment, individuality and isolation.

and instead of caring more for my things, my experiences, my contexts, my relationships, my community, my landscape. Yet every night I fall victim to fatigue, and find myself promising myself that I will wake up early to return, fresh, to the key issues that grip me.

Even if my work, fortunately, allows me to be 100% authentic, I feel a need to integrate new priorities, to connect everything I do, to develop a greater integrity in caring less for the problems of others (even if they are clients who pay me handsomely to do so)...

Every day I think about the many things I will write, or in general would like to work on in the evening.  Things that never find a place in my day focused on production.  These are projects of change, new priorities, perhaps more authentic interests.

This doesn't mean that can't be applied anywhere in DAOs/web3 space.

Not much more. Seeing such an overlap between DAOs and traditional horizontal, self managed, sociocratic orgs means missing macroscopic points imo and projecting a model designed for different context/age into a new and radically different one.

On the other you've those involved in the scalable/role-based part of the organisation (the architected). Decision making, gov. structures are totally different, sociocracy can probably partially help with the gov *between* founding/key nodes (despite normally very independent).
This institutional structure has to manage treasury, allocate work to  nodes, potentially onboard other nodes and in some cases the responsibility of kicking off a progressive decentralisation.

On one hand you've nodes/teams that engage with entrepr. bootstrap, they often create equity-like assets such as utility/governance tokens, & build the institutional structure (eg foundation) + decision making (dependent on domain, context): they effectively are the architects.

My impression is a tad different. These technology (BFT consensus / smart contracts, programmable assets) make fundamentally new patterns possibile. Imo there are at least two layers of contribution (or more generally a gradient between the extremes).
So now the mood of the day is that  DAOs are just like any other organizations based on shared governance and you just need a pinch of sociocracy and you got it sorted out.

layer 5 + 6 can be left to competing, revenue-maximizing entities: likely multiple user experiences will be developed and aggregation can create defensibilities at that layer (through network effects)

The governing alliance will need to issue tokens to ensure that (1) decisions can be made based on contribution (2) the underlying protocol/info network (that will be based on the shared domain-model) can be produced maintaining consensus (eg: with staking/validation nodes.

essentially, the *network* will need to own, produce and govern layers 1-4 with the aim of ensuring permissionlessness, and interface openness. Layers 1-4 (ecosystemic commons) will likely be subject to a "progressive decentralization" pattern.

5. a Workflow (product) and Extensions layer, where a set of use cases will be made available to end users and extensions can be built by third parties;

6. a Services Marketplace layer where the connection between different players be can be facilitated.

4. a governance structure, aimed at creating the possibility for institutions, and organizations of all kinds, to participate in the production, evolution & governance of the 3 layers described above (the protocol, the shared infrastructure, and the network enablement services).

3. a set of network enablement services provided to all members of  the network including a full-stack software architecture to allow the development of commercial initiatives such as SaaS, marketplaces, plug-ins, and more;
2. a shared infrastructure for transparent and untamperable data persistence of informational and financial transactions;

I think I'm on it. I'm identifying a pattern for the development of ecosystemic strategies based on 6 layers:
1. an open protocol (domain model) that abstracts the domain of the interactions, the entities, the workflows and the transactions;
I think we've to move from #GoToMarket to #GoToEcosystem
Check it out #3EO https://t.co/weuvZlpbcZ

3. We're now moving into ecosystemic organizing the transaction is much less dictated/specified: the reduction of tr. cost allows contracts 2b signed easily. Digitalization allows easy distribution of revenues, equity ...making it easier to engage w and distribute #skininthegame
2. Then we moved into the age of marketplaces where essentially the transaction is heavily modeled and scaled, the role of produced is allowed but encased/constrained in a role;

In terms of evolution:

1. We started with complicated and dumb contracts = bureaucracies: amassing suppliers, contractualize them for the long term, the only part of the transaction that was left on the market was purchasing (consumer);

Haier's EMC (self-managed and self-defined multi-sided smart contracts aimed at creating a certain outcome) is a kind of *evolution* of a transaction: as transaction cost plummets complex (smart) contracts can become the new transactions, reducing the need to rely on scale.

I 'm reflecting on this since a while.

On markets today: on one hand we're seeing ultra-specific domain models (marketplaces) and on the other end very generic/horizontal contracting platforms, such as Haier's rendanheyi and its supporting software

5th key learning: don't make things unnecessarily complicated. Despite I agree that you can't be "partially" decentralized, sometimes - and especially at the start - you don't need a 100% decentralized system, you can "progressively decentralize" as @jessewldn @ntnsndr pointed
4th key learning: Staking as the new key primitive of trust in web 3 (staking). This is a massive insight: how do you pour #skininthegame everywhere into the marketplace? STAKING.
3rd key learning: scaling at @braintrust has happened through incentives alignment (referrals, quality vetting, etc...) these are all network functions that are played by the community.

2nd key learning: @gabelunao is an experienced marketplace builder. He (& team) imagined that dropping fees to zero would make a whole new type of transactions possible (average transaction value on @usebraintrust is around 100k$ just impressive)

1st key learning: at @usebraintrust there's no equity. @gabelunao always calls "the network" (never "the company").
I've the feeling that rasing through SAFT + seeing the gov. token being listed is a new, and complexity friendly, way to valorize the network (vs liquidity events)

Empowering freedom of entrepreneurship I believe can bring our societal focus back to users, communities and landscape wellbeing, allowing for a new human development thesis to unfold around economies based on relationships and a plurality of human expression.

I believe that empowering the small teams to be self-directed and create contextual solutions versus replicating - potentially harmful - top-down directions and strategies can provide a new lens to reducing human harm on the planet.

I believe that to enable this revolution we need new software technologies that enable these patterns with ease and tear down the barriers between organizations thanks to shared protocols & domain models, distributed data, and coordination infrastructures based on the blockchain.

These organizations, I argue, will grow organically by empowering the edges: teams will be able to dynamically configure, and get strength in their own contexts without the need to be militarily managed in a top-down manner to execute a vision coming from the center.

I believe that - as a consequence of the plummeting transaction cost and the pervasive nature of modern technology - the dynamic, widespread, software-enabled use of contracts represents a new frontier for designing and running a new kind of 21C native organization.

I'll stop here because there's already too much for a twitter thread but you can look into:
1) strategically using pricing depending on the development phase
2) relating pricing to Unit Economics 
...and more by reading the full post here: https://t.co/ta6EuHAWoV

In more complex ecosystems, transactions can happen also inside the extension (often as micro-payments): and brands have been often battling around enforcing certain payment channels to their extensions or app builders. The obvious reference here is Apple's battle with Epic Games

Monetizing the extension providers (developers) normally comes through: an integration fee, one-time or recurring, needed to create or publish the extensions, and a take rate on the purchase of the extension (if paid) or of any other digital element purchased (through it).

The 3rd major context of a platform's pricing strategy is the so-called "extension platform". Extension platforms are used by platform-marketplace owners to extend the value proposition of the product side of their platforms. @Salesforce Appexchange is a great example.

In a few words, the more the platform's value proposition is in the "transaction engine" - depending on network effects based demand aggregation - the more you'll need to operate on low margins, falling back on competitor-based pricing and cost-based pricing.

According @Patticus: "A value metric is essentially what you charge for. For example: per seat, per 1,000 visits, per CPA, per GB used, per transaction, etc‚Ä¶if you get everything else wrong in pricing, but you get your value metric right, you'll do ok"

In particular, pricing a SaaS is a fairly mature matter, but the first thing you need to understand in that context is the so-called Value Metric. Once you understand your value metric you can pursue several approaches to building a contextual pricing strategy.

When supply is not commoditized but can be owned by the platform (through exclusivity or other reasons) the platform has dramatically more leverage in setting the price. Netflix, for example, provides the whole inventory at a fixed monthly subscription price.
In case the services sold are frequently purchased commodities (rides) price is normally set by the platform.

Take rates impact the consumer side pricing on your marketplace, but the price that suppliers set is also a fundamental driver of consumers' willingness to pay for P/S. Depending on the nature of the supply marketplaces may or may not be able to apply certain pricing strategies.

Instead professional hosts (like hotels and some other hosts) the guest doesn't get any visible "service fee" and the host is charged around 14‚Äì16%. The articulated way that Airbnb uses to define its take rates is a good example of how strategic one can be about it.

Another aspect defining the take rate in a marketplace is who to take it from: @Airbnb has a fairly articulated fee structure on the take rate. For non-professional hosts it's around 3% (up 6% in some cases) and ~14% on the guest's side.
As Lilian Chen points out in her "A Comparison of Take Rates: Drivers of Value" (https://t.co/62y2d4Baxq ) : https://t.co/xh5S1mzcNc

Another key aspect of sizing a good take rate comes from understanding the so-called BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement). Both sides of the transaction (supply and demand) normally consider alternatives to transacting on the platform

Here's a stack of the things that need to be done Clearly, the more of this is taken over by the platform owners - instead of the providers - the more the owner of the platform is entitled to take a bigger rate of the transaction's value. https://t.co/0bLP48O0Ey

Key aspect to consider when setting a take rate: what's the actual contribution of the marketplace and how is that perceived by the entities in the transactions? A number of things need to be executed to ensure a good transaction and the platform owners normally takes over some.

The most important aspect of (1) is the sizing the *Take-Rate* you should apply. Take rates vary a lot in marketplaces: from as little as 5% where the owner mainly takes care of the intermediation, up to 80% (stock photo). In most cases the higher take rate is around 30%.

One of the highlights of a recent conversation we had with @JamesCurrier was that as we move into more vertical/managed marketplace opportunities, a mix of platform-provided services often complements the "transactional" nature of the marketplace and pricing becomes strategic

Highlight #5 ‚Äî Again and again, company‚Äôs culture matters: despite incremental improvements is key‚Ää-‚Ääsometimes you need to take big bets, crazy ideas and sometimes big risks... they can be the much-needed needle movers.

Highlight #4 ‚Äî Different contexts and platform size determine which growth strategies apply.
Sometimes Liquidity is essential and brute-force/all hands on deck works: other times the growth needs to be contextual, in niches, categories, geographies and contexts. It depends

Highlight #3 ‚Äî Acquisition versus Engagement and Retention: there‚Äôs a big focus on acquisition, land grab and building up that network, especially if it‚Äôs a product that has #nfx: but what happens is as you get bigger and bigger? retention and engagement become more important.

Highlight #2 ‚Äî Team Structure and Roles: how they work and execute.  You need fast, nimble and decentralised teams. A minimum common denominator: the interconnectedness of the various specialisations among teams and, even within the same team, mixing different backgrounds.

Highlight #1 ‚Äî Channel-Product fit must be your obsession: one really needs to understand what users are trying to achieve and where to meet them ‚Äî where they are. That‚Äôs why you need to find the right channels for the right product: growth is more inward-looking than expected
